steps.title: Find the head of the tick.
steps.content: Find the head of the tick. If you look closely, you'll see its mouth attached to the skin, with the body resting behind it. [1] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Grasp the tick as close to the skin as possible with a pair of tweezers.
steps.content: Grasp the tick as close to the skin as possible with a pair of tweezers. Use tweezers with fine tips, rather than blunt ones, to make sure you are able to grasp the tick tightly. [2] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source Don't try this with your fingers. You won't be able to get a good, tight grip on the tick. Make sure you're gripping the tick's head. Get the tweezers as close to the mouth of the tick as possible. Do not grasp the tick's body. This can cause it to inject saliva or blood into your skin and increase the chances of transmitting a disease. [3] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Pull firmly and steadily outward.
steps.content: Pull firmly and steadily outward. The tick's mouth will release the skin. Do not twist, jerk, or wiggle the tweezers as you pull, or the tick's mouth parts may remain attached to the skin. It's not uncommon for the skin to also pull up as the tick detaches, much like it does when you pluck a stray hair. [4] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source If the mouth parts remain attached, attempt to remove them with the tweezers. If they're buried in the skin, you can simply let the skin heal, checking it from time to time to make sure it doesn't become infected. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Wash with warm water and soap.
steps.content: Wash with warm water and soap. You can also use rubbing alcohol, hydrogen peroxide, or iodine. Clean both the bite and your hands thoroughly. [6] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: See a doctor if you have trouble removing the tick.
steps.content: See a doctor if you have trouble removing the tick. Some ticks are so small that they're difficult to remove using this common method. A doctor will be able to remove the tick for you. [7] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Cut a length of floss.
steps.content: Cut a length of floss. Choose a thin, unwaxed floss, or another type of thin string. This does the trick if you don't have tweezers on hand. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Loop the string around the tick's head.
steps.content: Loop the string around the tick's head. The string should lie as close to the skin as possible. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Tighten the loop around the head.
steps.content: Tighten the loop around the head. Use both hands to pull the floss taut. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Pull the ends of the string upward in a slow, steady motion.
steps.content: Pull the ends of the string upward in a slow, steady motion. The tick's mouth will release the skin. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Wash with warm water and soap.
steps.content: Wash with warm water and soap. Clean both the bite and your hands. Rubbing alcohol, hydrogen peroxide, or iodine can also be used to help prevent infection and the spreading of tick-borne disease. [12] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Cut a V-shape into the card.
steps.content: Cut a V-shape into the card. Using a pair of scissors, cut a small V-shape along the edge of the card. It should be large enough to grab the tick, but not so large that the tick slips through.

steps.title: Slide a credit card next to the tick's head.
steps.content: Slide a credit card next to the tick's head. Slide the credit card between your skin and the tick, aligning the V-cut with the tick's head. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Firmly hold the back of the tick in place.
steps.content: Firmly hold the back of the tick in place. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Slide the credit card along your skin and under the head.
steps.content: Slide the credit card along your skin and under the head. After a few tries, the tick should come out whole. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Dispose of the tick properly.
steps.content: Dispose of the tick properly. The tick will probably still be alive when you remove it. You can soak it in rubbing alcohol or flush it down the toilet to prevent it from attaching itself to you or your loved ones. [16] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: Consider saving the tick for testing.
steps.content: Consider saving the tick for testing. If ticks in your area are known to frequently carry Lyme disease, you might want to save the tick in case you need to get it tested. Place it in a plastic food storage bag, seal the bag, then put it in the freezer. Find a lab that does tick testing and follow instructions for properly submitting the tick. [17] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Check the wound site for symptoms.
steps.content: Check the wound site for symptoms. In the weeks following the tick removal, check the site for signs that you may have contracted Lyme Disease or another tick-borne illness. You'll need to tell your doctor when you noticed the tick, when you removed it, and what subsequent symptoms youâ€™re experiencing. If you notice the following symptoms developing, see a doctor immediately: [18] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source A fever and/or chills. This is a common symptom of tick-borne illnesses. Headaches and muscle aches. The tell-tale bulls-eye rash. This is a symptom of Lyme disease as well as Southern Tick-Associated Rash Illness (STARI). Red patches create a bulls-eye pattern around the site of the tick bite, so watch out for this. [19] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source Any other type of rash. Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (RMSF), also carried by ticks, can cause a rash that does not look like a bulls-eye to appear. [20] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source
